Reviews.Content: The hotel overlooks the World Trade Center in the Financial District. It is not right in the middle of the touristy sites, but it's so easy to get around via the subway. (The Gray Line bus tour has a stop just on the other side of the block too!) The hotel itself is very nice. Tall and skinny, so it has the feel of a smaller hotel, with about 10 rooms on each floor. The rooms were average size, nicely furnished, and with such an incredible view of the WTC site, World Financial Center buildings, the river, and beyond into New Jersey. We didn't have much interaction with the staff, but they seemed friendly. And when I asked at the front desk for more shampoo, someone came to the room within 15 minutes with a whole bag of extra toiletries. We really enjoyed our stay!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel, Disappointing Guest Service”
Reviews.Author: Cubzter
Reviews.Content: Overall, the Millennium Hilton is very close to being a very solid hotel. The facilities are excellent, but serious guest service problems keep this hotel from reaching its full potential. It is very unfortunate that such a lovely facility is held back by repeated gaffes on the part of the staff. If they could iron out these wrinkles this property has the potential to really shine. But, as it is, the disappointing treatment by the staff is enough to take this off of hotels that I would return to. We booked this hotel for three nights at $180/night via Hotwire.com. This was an excellent value compared to similarly priced hotels in Midtown (where we prefer to stay) which were running in the $250+ range during that time. I did not penalize the hotel because of the location, that is not their fault and we had a good idea of what we were getting into by choosing to stay downtown on a weekend. Simply put, this area of NYC is dead on the weekends because it is the business center of the city. During this time restaurants and even the drug stores close very early--if they are open at all. Also, subway travel is very hit or miss to this area because they are rebuilding two of the stations and service is frequently suspended or re-routed during the weekends. Cabs are available at the hotel, with a ride to Midtown running $12-14 each way, plus tip. Ultimately, we felt very removed from the city and probably would not stay in this area again. Upon arrival we were checked in by a very friendly efficient staff member. The lobby, while compact, is beautiful. The rooms are quite spacious by New York City standards. Decor is very clean, almost minimalist in a palette of neutral colors. Furnishings are of upscale quality and in very good, almost new condition which makes sense as the hotel only reopened (after a full renovation) in 2003. The closet was small but did have plenty of hangers, a full-sized ironing board, and even two umbrellas (though I'd gladly trade the umbrellas for having robes in the room). The large flat screen television was nice, but we were disappointed with the poor picture quality on several channels and a remote control that only worked half of the time. Also, the on screen hotel services menu (where you can check your folio, check out, etc.) did not work. Because of the building's small footprint the rooms are only on the ends and one side of the building (as opposed to both sides), with end rooms being suites and middle rooms being the standard sized rooms. All standard rooms (such as the one we stayed in) view the WTC site and World Financial Center buildings (striking views). Windows near the elevators have superb views of the lower east side, Brooklyn Bridge, etc. Our service problems started almost immediately. We called guest services to request two additional pillows. They said they would be right up. After 45 minutes we received a call from guest services to confirm that they had arrived...which of course they hadn't. They apologized and said they would be right there. After another 45 minutes I called guest services to let them know we STILL hadn't received the pillows. Again, they apologized and said they would be right there. After 20 more minutes they did. Two phone calls and nearly TWO HOURS for extra pillows is ridiculous. This property touts "The Bed" by Hilton which is--supposedly--a premium bed. I found the mattress to be entirely too firm and NOT EVEN CLOSE to a Westin Heavenly bed. This is not a "pillow top" type of mattress but rather a regular inner spring mattress with a little add-on pad strapped to it. The linens were acceptable, though nothing special. Another disappointing issue for us was the lack of an in-room coffee maker...even Motel Six offers this basic feature. You shouldn't be required to get dressed, go downstairs and get coffee in the morning (and the coffee place is probably closed anyway because this is downtown on the weekend)...or be forced to pay $10/carafe with a $4 delivery fee and 15% service charge. Bathrooms are spacious and bright. Toiletries are Crabtree & Evelyn. The towels are very nice, designer type ones; however, I did notice that on the third day housekeeping started mixing much cheaper, lower quality, non-matching towels in with the good ones. Robes and slippers are only available by request and even then it took 45 minutes and two phone calls to get them (yet another problem with guest services). The robes were very scratchy and uncomfortable...I had not idea you could get cotton to feel that way. We dined using room service twice. The first time was perfect. Unfortunately the second time was a disaster. We called and they said they would call right back to take our order. After waiting 35 minutes for them to call back (unacceptable) we called again to find out the reason for the delay. They apologized and said they would call us right back to take our order (what is with the calling back thing, why can't they just take the order right then?). After another five minutes they did call back to take our order. The meal itself, was pretty much inedible (the french fries were mushy, and the burger incinerated). After returning to the hotel on our final night neither one of our keys would work so we had to go all the way back downstairs to have them recoded. The front desk person rather than simply apologizing and recoding them started implying that we must have done something to demagnetize them (what this might have been I can't even imagine). But apparently it was our fault by the way she reacted. Also related to staff issues, the doormen are VERY inconsistent with some bordering on rude. Once we even had to open the door ourselves while a doorman stood right beside the door.

Reviews.Title: “OK, if you get a good price”
Reviews.Author: Fla_Sailor
Reviews.Content: First, this Hilton has much more personality than most Hiltons. That is good. My room had large windows, and being high up, I had a spectacular view of the Brooklyn Bridge. Whatever they may get wrong here, you still have the view. Speaking of wrong, the room service was a horrible experience. The delivery time was twice what they quoted on the phone, and the food was just bad. The downstairs staff was friendly and courteous, better than other Hiltons. A subway location is almost right outside the door, so you can get updown very easily. Unfortunately, I didn't get such the deal other reviewers did. So for a price in the upper $200's, I would probably look elsewhere next time. If I could get it for about $200, I would book it.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We travel frequently to NYC, and stay at Hilton hotels, as I am a frequent business traveler and all of my stays have been reward stays. The Millenium was the fourth hotel in NYC that we tried. It was very clean, and indeed had plasma screen tv's as advertised. Twice we have stayed in the Time Square area, and it was very noisy in the room (New York Hilton). The traffic down in lower Manhattan is inconsequential and subsequently, we slept great. The bed is very comfortable, and the bathroom is average size. Overall, a nice hotel. The lobby isn't fancy, which I don't have a problem with, since at this hotel they used the money they saved and put it in the hotel rooms. If you're concerned about staying in a location that's not central, not too worry. The subway is right across the street, and cabs are readily available all hours of the day. A cab ride to the Rockerfeller Center area will run you about $10, a Lincoln Town Car about $25 - $30. I would definately stay at this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “WONDERFUL”
Reviews.Author: LoveTravels
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millienium last year in May for a weekend and loved it. The hotel does have a depressing view on one side (WTC site) but other than that there is nothing wrong with it. Even though outside our window was the site we still had a great view looking up and all the way to the river. The staff downstairs were great and cordial. The room was wonderful. Not large but considering NYC it was nothing to complain about. If you have a lot of bags than you might run into some issues but other than that there is no reason to be unhappy. Room and bathroom were clean, bed and sheets soft and comfy, and the flat screen hanging on the wall was also nice. The breakfast we got one morning with room service was not first rate but still satisfying with a generous stock of maple syrop, jam and honey. I really recommend this hotel to anyone who enjoys a nice place to come back to after a long day out on the town.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: mammymoo
Reviews.Content: This hotel is clean, spacious and modern with a plasma TV and nice beddings and bath. I have stayed at many other hotels in the city and like this one the best. Pro: Century 21 shopping is right next door! Con: The breakfast buffet could be alot better.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel in downtown manhattan”
Reviews.Author: gam1331
Reviews.Content: this hotel has got to be the best in downtown. when you walk in the hotel's small but welcoming lobby you are suprised by the hotels wonderful service (bellmen greet you, check-in staff make sure your taken of quickly, and they acommadate your needs). when i checked in they said i would have a high floor just as i rquested and since i was a part of hiltons frequent stay gold level program i recieved free breakfast at the hotels reastarant church & dey restaraunt which was good. now about the hotel dining theres only one restaraunt which is church & dey and for a nice meal its great becuase its never packed, its almost always empty since everyone goes out to eat at other local places (which i would also recomend to save money). oh yeah very important all elevator in the hotel are express which means they are very fast so you might get nervous but its really safe and quick. the rooms at this hotel are average size for new york, but are decorated really nice and beds are excellent, TIP : get a city view the view its great and you have a view of ground zero. now about touring, i recommend "the new york sightseeing gray line double decker bus "which is just fantastic it really is and i recommened you do the night loop on the bus, also do not take the other copycat buses there enclosed at the top and not as nice. if you plan on going to the empire state building go at night the view is breath taking only downside is the extreamly long lines but there is the brand new observatory at the rockefeller center called the "top of the rock" which has very short lines and better view but i would recommend going to the top of the rock observatory during the day when you can see central park and everything and empire state building at night. also time square is always busy and its where you board the night loop bus. if you have kids go to toy r us in time sqaure and f.a.o swarchtz on 5th ave. all in all it was a great hotel and new york city is very fun and had a great time.

Reviews.Title: “This Suite was Sweet”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: With play tickets for an evening show purchased,I looked on the different travel sites for something reasonable in LOWER MANHATTAN/SOHO. We like to walk around and experience the art of the city.(the subway is a $2.00, ten minute ride to Times Square) Frustrated by the non bargain-like prices, I went directly to the Hilton website, only to find a junior suite for $239.00.This was a deal! Check-in was speedy, our room on the 44th floor, gave us a majestic view of 911, and we were centrally located to do SOHO,TRIBECCA,and CANAL STREET, all in one afternoon. SPAMALOT was a big hit and so was this HILTON.

Reviews.Title: “Another great stay”
Reviews.Author: hardingk
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for another night prior to a business trip. Room was great, love the flat panel TV! Room Service was awesome, pool was good, gym was a little small. Overall it is a great hotel, in a good location for downtown NYC.

Reviews.Title: “New Year in New York”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millenium Hilton over New Year, we found the room to be clean and well presented. Bathroom and room were both spacious. We found all the staff we encountered to be helpful and friendly. The bed was very comfortable although the air conditioning was quite noisy. Our only criticism is that room service trays and dirty plates were left on corridors for days before being removed. We have stayed in New York a number of times and would recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Good Value”
Reviews.Author: rcr86
Reviews.Content: Last weekend I spent 2 nights at this hotel with a few friends from out of town for St Patricks Day weekend. The stay started out a little rocky since we were told that our car would be parked off site and we would not have access to it for the duration of our visit. I am guessing this is not uncommon in NYC, but still inconvienent. Then, when we checked in we were told at registration that the room had only one bed! This was unacceptable since there were 4 of us and my reservation had specifically stated that I had reserved a room with 2 beds. After assuring us that there were no rooms with two beds in the entire hotel (suites included) for nearly 10 minutes, they "magically" found one on the 42nd floor. I have to say they were pleasant during this entire process but it took some major patience and negotiating to resolve. Once these initial snafus were past us, the rest of the weekend was a blast! The room was immaculate and well stocked with towels and glasses and provided an impressive view uptown and of the Hudson. The cleaning staff did a excellent job and the concierge and bellman were all eager to help us enjoy our stay. The hotel location is in the Financial District so it tended to get a little quiet at night (it's no Times Square). However, there is a nice subway station at Ground Zero right in front of the hotel and taxi service from the side door (the actual front entrance was under construction while we were there). We found it easy to get anywhere from this hotel by using either the train ($2/per person) or getting a cab (usually less than $10). The only real gripe I have with the stay is that the room got really hot after the first night and there was no effective way to cool it down. Only one small section of our window would open and even then it only moved about 2 inches. It was 34 degrees out but our room constantly hovered around 80 degrees with the A/C on. The front desk said that their HVAC system was based on hot water so when it is heating season, there is no A/C and vice versa. This seems pretty archaic to me so, to future winter travelers I would recommend keeping a window open since you can always heat up the room if necessary. Overall the stay was good and we had a wonderful experience. I would definitely stay here again. PS Our beautiful 42" plasma TV was hobbled by a poor cable feed that created a crappy picture.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: It couldn't have been easier to find, straight accross the road from the station. We were a bit concerned that we would be too far away from the rest of New York but if you plan your days well, you can go to the top end (Central park) inc Time square etc one day, Little Italy, China Town etc another and then Statue of Liberty and Financial district another. The underground is easy to use once you learn what lines and stops are needed and walking part of the way is just delightful as you feel so involved in the wonderful city. The staff in the hotel were a bit business like and matter of fact but it was imaculate and with views over ground zero it was just fantastic and really made you think about what had happened on that dreadful day. We had a look at a hotel in the Time square area that we had tried to book and we would stay in that one another time.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Lorital/scar
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at this hotel From Nov 23- Dec 01 ,2005. We loved it. We booked it at a great rate which included buffet breakfast every day. It was our first time in New York and we were a little nervous. We found the Hotel staff was very helpful and friendly. The subway station right across the street (ground zero) was our ticket to seeing all the sights of New York. It was awesome having the subway station so close. The best part of this hotel was being right next to Century 21 ( that is if you are a shopper). It gave me a chance to check out all the great deals every day. I would head their every morning at 7:45 when it opens (my husband would still be in bed ) and check out all the new inventory and great deals ! I totally recommend this Hotel to anyone. The location is a little ways away from the business of time square but with the subway so conviently located it takes you know time to see all that new York has to offer. The rooms were spacious, clean and very nice. We loved the Plasma T.V

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: Geordieglobetrotter
Reviews.Content: We managed to get this hotel for an excellent price through Airline Network and it proved to be fantastic value for money. We landed just as the snow started falling and were lucky to get to the hotel before it fell really hard. We had no problems at all with the hotel, staff were fast and efficient during check in and check out, our room was great on the 17th floor, great beds, lots of room and as mentioned before, 42" plasma, which to be honest we didn't have time to watch other than to get updates on the weather. Each time we needed to take a taxi at night, the door staff were pleased to help. We used the pool and sauna one evening but found the pool a little cool. After lots of recommendations for Stage Door Deli just over the road, we ate breakfast there each morning and have to say that was a great. Everything you could want is done with no fuss and we got breakfast with drinks each day for under $10 for the two of us. We used the subway to get uptown each day and this was really easy and only took approx 5-10 mins, one word of warning beware of people telling you the ticket machine isnt taking cash and selling you an all day pass for $7, this happened to us at Chamber St Station and the ticket we were given was just a single journey ticket which would cost just $2 The man looked like he worked at the subway so naively we trusted him. After that we just bought our ticket from the machine or ticket booth. We ate at some great places, fistly a place in Tribeca which we walked to from the hotel, called Edwards, a nice friendly bistro, good food at good prices. Our second night we thought we would try Chinatown, this turned out to be a big disappointment as there were very few places to eat that were open and when we did find one we were told we couldn't come in, for what reason we will never know, anyway not to be deterred we carried on walking to Little Italy and came across a busy place (considering how much snow was on the ground) called Amici's II, again great service from our waiter called Fabrizio and lovely food at good prices. He even got us a private car home at the end of the evening. Our final night was at a restaurant called Garage in Greenwich Village, this was fantastic, live jazz music each night, superb food and service from our waiter Keith who looked after us so well. I would recommend this place to anyone planning a visit to NY. Anyone want anymore info please feel free to email me.

Reviews.Title: “Very Impressed”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Check in and check out was a breeze. The bellman who helped us to the front desk was superb. He was very helpful and very attentive. The room was very clean, very comfortable and cozy. Room service was very fast. The prices are a little expensive, but in comparison to other hotels we've stayed at, the prices would be considered reasonable. My only gripe about this hotel is that parking is $48/night w/o in/out privileges. But overall, the experience was excellent. The next time I visit NY, I will definitely stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic value for money!”
Reviews.Author: harveybunny123
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Hilton for my hubbys 40th birthday from 10-13th Feb (during the Blizzard of '06!). I booked the Hilton because it was reasonably priced and was not disappointed. We had a lovely room on the 31st floor with a view over the World Trade Centre site, and it was clean and comfortable. The bed was to die for and we slept well!! I had absolutely no complaints whatsoever with regards to the hotel. The staff were friendly and helpful, we never saw any cleaning staff, but the rooms were always done very swiftly and to a high standard. The Stage Door Deli is a must for breakfast, lunch or dinner! The guys in there are fabulous and its very clean with great food. The area is quiet at night and on first glance seems everything is closed at about 8 but if you walk a little further down Church St you come to Tribeca and there are lots of food places there. We ate at Mary Annes which is a mexican and really lovely. We would stay there again without hesitation!

Reviews.Title: “excellent”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Compared to other hotels in midtown, this hotel is not a bad deal $$ wise for extremely clean and new rooms. The bed is probably one of the most comfortable beds I have ever slept on. The 42" plasma screen tv was great. Everything about this hotel is great. It is about a 10 dollar cab ride to Grand Central Station, or if you prefer there is a subway stop right outside the hotel. HIGHLY recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Quality hotel with hidden supprises”
Reviews.Author: brick_driver
Reviews.Content: Just got back after a long weekend in the Big Apple with my wife. We decided on the Millennium Hilton because of the good price that was on offer when we booked through Expedia, plus I didn't fancy staying in a midtown hotel. Overall I have to say that the service at this hotel was some of the best I have had at a 4*+ hotel. The staff would answer the phone after on ring and there was always someone to hand on the main desk. The rooms were large by New York standards, we had a King deluxe suite, and were well appointed with high speed internet access, plenty of stationary, Crabtree & Evelyn bath products, digital climate control, three setting power shower and the infamous 42" plasma screen. The standard king size "The Bed" is one of the most comfortable beds I have stayed in and was well received after all the walking we did. As for the view, we were on the 21st floor and we had a fabulous view of the Hudson River. As for the view of Ground Zero, whilst it is sobering the first time you see it from up high you quickly realise that New York and its residents have moved on and won't let it get the better of them and soon you feel the same way. I read in a previous review about the Stage Door Deli located on Vesey Street. This place serves up some of the best "Hero's" in New York at very reasonable prices. The breakfast is bigger, nicer and 1/3 of the price in the hotel. The swimming pool and sauna is a nice addition and like the bed is very welcome after a long day out. Century 21 located next door is a must. I picked up a pair of Hugo Boss jeans for $90 reduced from $180. There are bargains all over the store and the place is busy all day with long queues for the changing rooms. Now for the hidden surprise. Hilton charges a fee of $75 per night to cover incidentals. This is deducted from your credit card when you check in. If, like myself, you rely on you credit card it can come as a surprise when your card is rejected. As with European hotels your credit card details are taken when you check in but instead of assessing any costs and deducting them from your card when you check out, they deduct $75 per night there and then. They do not tell you that they will deduct it straight away nor is it explained in any of their literature. I was told that it did explain on the Hilton website but as I did not book through their website I did not read this. I tried to get the money back after the embarrassment of having my card refused only to be told that because it was the weekend they couldn't do anything until the Monday. Now as this was on a Saturday it left us with little money and forced us to eat and drink at the hotel. So make sure you have this covered. Also beware of what the bellboys call a taxi. Out side the hotel will be rows of black cars/limos. Whilst they are licensed by the T&LC they operate a fixed rate and not metered. We took one of these cars from the hotel to the Empire State building and it cost us $24 (without tip) where as the taxi back cost $15 (including tip). However, these cars come in handy going back to JFK because the fixed rate is $50 regardless of how long it takes to get there whereas a taxi is on a meter and it took us nearly an hour to get to the airport at 2pm.

Reviews.Title: “Superb with humble views of ground zero”
Reviews.Author: dave1976
Reviews.Content: Stayed here from feb 3rd to feb 6th and had an excellent stay. Rooms were a good size (twice as big as The Time hotel) and had a huge very comfortable bed. The room service was prompt and we found the food of a good standard. The maids were very good and kept our room very tidy with fresh towels every day. The views of ground zero are very humbling and cannot be avoided. All in all an excellent time and we wouldnt fail to recommend this hotel to anyone, the only complaint is its a fair distance from time square although right next to a tube entrance and taxis are fairly easy to hail.

Reviews.Title: “Poorly managed”
Reviews.Author: sierrarancher
Reviews.Content: Worst issue: after cleaning my room the housekeeper left the door completley open. Granted I had left most important things in the safe deposity box, all my PC realted stuff was out. Also, I didn't know if there was anyone lurking in the room. Pretty scary stuff. Second, food is terrible. Third, breakfast room service tray was left in the hallway all day long, wasn't picked up until after 7pm. There were trays all over the hallway. What a messy and unsanitary look. Get it together , and have someone walk the halls every few hours to pick up trays. I won't be returning.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing beats the views!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Though rooms are nice there are hotels with nicer rooms for sure, though the restaurant is ok there are hotels with nicer restaurants for sure, but nothing beats the views from the upper floors of this downtown hotel! stayed the second time for a whole week in january and had the good luck to get a corner room on 53rd floor with a view that reached from old city hall and municipal building in the north over east river with manhattan and brooklyn bridges, brooklyn, downtown, the statue of liberty to hudson river, jersey city, world finance center and ground zero. Enjoying that view at any time of the day made the huge plasma tv remain switched off the whole week! Even from the restaurant on third floor the view over ground zero and world finance center to new jersey is magnificent! Add an indoor pool for bad-weather-days, stops of 12 subway lines within 3 minutes walk, the proximity of Tribeca, SoHo, Chinatown .. and sometimes even reasonable rates .. all that makes it my favourite hotel in new york! We'll be back!

Reviews.Title: “Love the Millenium Hilton”
Reviews.Author: bridge13
Reviews.Content: My daughter two grand daughters 12 and 7 years and myself arrived at this lovely hotel on 26th December. The lobby had a beautiful Christmas Tree and the trees outside the hotel were smothered with fairly lights. Our Junior suite on the 54th floor overlooking Ground Zero and also with a view of the Statue of Liberty was excellent, spotlessly clean, the bathroom luxurious, plenty of soft fluffy towels and toiletries. The staff we encountered from every department, even security, when one child locked the other one out of the room and would not let her in and she was crying out in the corridoor, were couteous and helpful. The the nicest surprize was on our last evening after a very busy day and returning to our room late evening we decided to have room service for dinner. It was fantastic, the food was excellent, served from a trolly that turned into a table for four, beautiful china, cutlery and linen a carnation in a small bud vase and a most attentive waiter and no more expensive that the restaurants we went to on previous days. All those things and in such an accessable position, a few steps from the subway and so much quieter than in the heart of the city. I highly reconmend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel but some service issues”
Reviews.Author: buddyandme
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Hilton Millenium for three nights Jan. 3-6 2006. Stayed on the 54th floor in a king parlor corner suite. I doubt there could be better views from any room in any hotel in NYC. Hudson River to the west, with magnificent sunsets. East River to the east with beautiful views of Brooklyn Bridge. Out the center windows Ground Zero and beyond. The views at night were the most beautiful with buildings and bridges sparkling in all three directions. The room was wonderful. Seperate bedroom with master bath including seperate shower and tub. Large living area with couches, chairs, and dining table. Our daughters slept on pull out sofa and had their own bath. Could not have asked for a nicer suite for our family. Service issues-room not ready when we arrived so desk clerk told us baggage handlers would store baggage. Much appreciated. Asked concierge who to arrange this with and they continued their joking and laughing and pointed toward bellmen. Asked a bellman and he pointed to another bellman. That bellman held up his hand to me to stop my request mid-sentence, informed me he was helping somebody else. Poor customer service. Room service was slow, expensive, and the food was poor. Twice attempted to get something from gift shop and both times found sign on the door "be right back". If not for these issues, could be a five star hotel. Saw two shows, Wicked and The Producers. Both were great. Exhibit at South St. Sea Port called "Bodies" amazing and should not be missed. Human cadavers donated to science have been treated,preserved, and displayed to allow people to see bones,muscles,organs,pathological conditions such as a brain that has suffered a stroke, smokers vs. non-smokers lung etc. This was done with taste and dignity. A great educational experience. The Stage Deli, as always has the best deli food and enormous, well worth the calories desserts. The Stage Door Deli across from the Millenium Hilton is not related, not really that good, and there was a mouse running around between tables when we were there. Would have been nice to have in room coffee but Starbucks and bagels just around the corner. China town great fun and great food. Great city, great trip, and great hotel suite. Would stay again despite service issues because suite and views so nice.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic value, great views”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Just back from New York and a three night stay in the Millenium Hilton and I can really recommend it. The rooms are good, a decent size for New York (which means basically that they are quite small), but everything is clean and new. Staff are helpful. The best things about this hotel are the price, around £110 a night, booked in advance on Hilton's own site, the swimming pool (rare to get one in NY), plus small sauna, which overlooks St Pauls church, the flat screen tv, and the views from the windows. Our room was on the 52nd floor and looked out over the Hudson river, which was fascinating at any time of the day or night - boats, helicopters and planes flying by. The hotel also overlooks ground zero, which might be a problem for some. There are several subways within a few minutes walk which will take you uptown quickly, and Battery Park (for the Statue of Liberty), Tribeca and Little Italy and Chinatown are within 20 mins or less walk. We also stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, which was fantastic, the best hotel I have ever stayed in, but at nearly 4 times the price, it had to be. This had a bath with flat screen tv, separate shower and double sink, great views of NY, great bed, good music and tv entertainment system also flat screen, with your own DVD player. It was worth it as it was our honeymoon, but unless I have another honeymoon soon, I'll go to the Millenium Hilton

Reviews.Title: “A worthy contender”
Reviews.Author: PinballPenny
Reviews.Content: This is a nice hotel. we enjoyed staying here. the room was very comfortable with a large plasma TV. Loads of in room movies that were very reasonable $8-12 each. The room had an in room safe, iron ironing board, nice toiletries hairdryer and 2 phones. The bathroom was a nice size with a tub and shower. we were on the 19th floor and weren't troubled by street noise, however, and it is a biggy, this hotel is beside ground zero. I found it unsettling to be sleeping and having fun so close to an area of such tragedy, and it is right outside the window. The hotel can't help that, and they have no control of the other problem. They are starting to rebuild the site now. The building work starts at about 7 am and goes on for a good 12 hours. We obviously never mentioned it is it sadly has to be done, but you don't usually deliberately book a hotel beside such a mammoth building site. You do get the hotel for a very good rate, so if you are aware of the building works, and are comfortable with being so close to ground zero then it is a very good choice. One thing that badly let the hotel down was the service and the food. We had free breakfast vouchers, and some mornings I couldn't even face it for free! It is very expensive if you do have to pay. 3 blueberry pancakes for example were $16! As to the service, we checked in late so the receptionist said to go to bed he would put the breakfast vouchers under the door. the following morning it took 5 phone calls to get them, by which time we had missed breakfast all together, so my advice - don't leave reception without everything you need! they did give us free room service in the end, which was lovely, fresh and hot, so well worth considering. Everyones Room service trays however stay in the hall from breakfast until 8 - 10 at NIGHT! and it was often after 2 pm before they serviced the room, so that was slow and inconvenient if you need to go back or have visitors, like we did. They do offer a turn down service too, some nights, but not all, there were chocolates! I stay in a lot of hiltons to collect the points. This one has the comfort but not the service, it feels like they have cut back on staff as they have to price it so low, which is a shame as it is a very good choice, good travel links and no changes on the subway from the airport you just catch the A train and get off at Fulton Street. An easy walk to the Brooklyn bridge and your first sight of the statue of liberty! well worth considering, if you are comfortable with ground zero.

Reviews.Title: “It does exactly what it says on the label”
Reviews.Author: SwingSinger
Reviews.Content: No doubting its a very good hotel. But...it IS a Hilton and had we not had the view over Ground Zero we could have been in a Hilton Hotel in any number of large cities. At least you know what you are getting. Special mention has to go to Joe one of the concierge, and Steve one of the Doormen. Excellent service above and beyond. Joe managed to get us booked into a New Years Eve Dinner Dance at a restaurent within 5 mins walk of the hotel at less that 24hr notice and it was fantastic value at $150 for two inc 4 courses + live music + an open bar 9-12pm. Steve managed to get us an immaculate stretched limo for our trip to see Fiddler on the Roof at just $35 door to door!! Thanks guys. The extortionate prices of the hotels breakfast ($22pp) can easily be avoided. There ARE a number of good restaurants and deli/diners for that authentic NYC breakfast or brunch in the Financial District. The Stage Door Deli / Essex Cafe and Paninis are all within a few hundred metres and offer great value for money and are recommended both for food quality and that edgy NYC atmosphere. For dinner we would heartily recommend Giovanni's Atrium ( Italian ) and Les Halles ( French ) both exellent and again within easy walking distance. O'Haras Bar/Restaurant next to the Fire Station adjacent to Ground Zero is 'ok' but couldn't be recommended, pretty basic food and service, and not that cheap. Worth seeing/doing while you are there? USS Intrepid, Circle Line Boat Trip, Central Park etc. At the Empire State Building, avoid the queues and buy the virtual flight tickets off the guys in the yellow jackets who will offer you tickets while you are in the queue for the Empire. Sure its a few extra dollars but it will save you anything up to a 3 to 4hr wait. Another alert! We bought a City Pass book for a number of attractions prior to going. It states in the City Pass that it allows you to beat the queues and go straight to the front of the line....it doesn't work, you will be directed to joint the queue at the back just like everyone else. National History Museum adjacent to Central Park.It's good BUT probably needs at least two days to do it justice. Cabs were an total lottery. We had the full spectrum from a genuine new yorker type ( a la De Niro )who was great. The other end of the scale was an atrocious driver of far eastern origin who it seemed had little or no idea of geography or driving skills and even decided to stop for petrol and take a leak while the meter was left running and added about $3 to the bill...bizarre. For real night time entertainment either head for Chinatown ( Winnies is fun, although not for the faint hearted ). Swing46 a really cool Jazz Bar/Restaurant on 46th Street offers a great value fixed price 3 course meal for $22 before 7.30pm, ideal for pre theatre eats. Just along the street from there is a great piano/singalong bar where you will be entertained by Broadway singers for the price of your beers. The Oyster Bar on the lower level at Grand Central Station should not be missed. New York really is spectacular. Overall a great 50th Birthday trip. I just need a holday to get over it now!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “GREAT HOTEL WITH FANTASTIC VIEWS”
Reviews.Author: Annie40
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel with my husband and two children (aged 9 & 13) over Xmas and New Year. We had a corner room on the 45th floor with large windows overlooking Ground Zero and The Statue of Liberty on one side and Brooklyn & Manhattan Bridge on the other side. The room was large enough for the four of us and bigger than most I have stayed in across Europe. The only thing we would have liked in the room is tea & coffee making facilities, but they did provide bottled water in the room every day at no cost. The indoor pool was a real bonus for us as the children enjoyed a swim after a long days sightseeing. All the hotel staff were very helpful and friendly. Getting to Midtown was very easy, a taxi outside the hotel cost between $10- $15. The Subway was another option and cost $2 each or you could buy a pass making it cheaper per trip. You can get a really good breakfast at The Stage Door Deli across the road. On a previous trip I stayed in Times Square at The Marriott Marquis, which was equally as nice but did not have a pool. I would recommend this hotel to anyone wanting a good quality hotel with a pool who doesn't mind getting a taxi or Subway into Midtown (takes about 20 mins). We went to Central Park on New Years Eve and saw some amazing fireworks and a midnight run.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: polarbear123
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millenium Hilton on December 3. The prices were high throughout New York since it was prime shopping season. We chose to stay here as it seemed like the nicest hotel for the money. I booked through the Hilton website about 1 month prior to our visit. In the final week the price dropped $200. I called the hotel to ask for an adjustment and they accomdated me quite politely. Be sure to watch the prices as your date gets closer! The hotel overall was nice. The room was on the small side, but from what I hear this is typical. It was very clean and comfortable. Our room was over looking Ground Zero. As my husband put it, if you could throw a rock out the window you would hit it. It was a distance from Midtown but the cabs were always available. Overall we enjoyed our stay here and would consider it again.

Reviews.Title: “Very enjoyable - just a couple of minus points”
Reviews.Author: MaggieJones
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed in this hotel for 5 nights late December. Our room was very pleasant and comfortable. It was great to be so close to the subway until the strike!! However we were able to use the PATH train to get to 33rd street. Staff were OK but didn't help at all in terms of how to get to JFK during a transit strike - we got good advice from fellow travellers on the trains that were running. No tea or coffe facilities in room and very expensive restaurant/bar. Would recommend the Italian restaurant ECCO which is about 15 minutes walk away and also the Salaam (not sure of spelling) Bombay - both excellent and not too expensive. The church next door is well worth a visit as it has moving displays re. 9/11 - you could walk past it and not know!

Reviews.Title: “Only if you have to....”
Reviews.Author: Spuggers
Reviews.Content: The Millenium Hilton is an ok hotel in an ok location but there are many better options in New York. the rooms are tired and the bathrooms need updating. The facilities in the room are sparse without even a trouser press or even bathrobes unless you ask! the rooms are quite noisy on every floor. The staff are friendly-ish. The restaurant has a very limited choice. Overall the hotel is fine if you need to stay downtown or have a corporate arrangement but if you are a tourist in New York, its only key advantage is proximity to Ground Zero and Century21 (the discount department store).

Reviews.Title: “Highly recommend”
Reviews.Author: Tropicmd
Reviews.Content: Just got back from a 3 day trip to Manhattan and stayed at the Millenium Hilton. It was fantastic. Very clean, excellent amenities, and the staff was courteous and helpful. And it's right next to Ground Zero. The only downside...expensive!! But everything in Manhattan is expensive. If I have to pay around $400 for a hotel room in New York, I might as well stay at a four star luxury such as the Millenium, which by the way, has a 42 inch flatscreen in every room. I recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking for a reliable place for a trip to Manhattan.

Reviews.Title: “Didn't care for it”
Reviews.Author: ShawnH
Reviews.Content: I just joined this great site and felt I owed a post. First of all, I found the location depressing. This hotel is like a NYC "sliver" building, and every window overlooks what is essentially a mass grave. Its a bizarre, alienating experience to walk around in your skivvies as your room seems to positively overhang this great, grey chasm. Speaking of windows, seemed to me the building was redone rather shabbily after 9/11, and the curtain wall exterior is too thin and lets in too much noise. I had to change rooms because one of the enormous windows was flexing and popping in the wind. Lastly, don't pay extra for a suite unless you really need a separate office. From what I can see, a "suite" gets you pretty much the same floor space as a standard room, only chopped into two too-small roomlets by placing the bathroom between. If you do stay, the standard room is nicer.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: Fozzie21
Reviews.Content: My husband whisked me away to New York City for my Christmas present, needless to say I was blown away by the city and the hotel. The view from our room was great, the floor to ceiling windows and flat screen TV were nice touches and the bed was possibly the most comfortable either of us have slept in. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful and the lift was super quick! Would recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “A fine place to kip!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My partner her daughter and myself stayed for 6 nights from 19th November. A great place with good staff, however some of the bellhops do try and get you to ride in unlicensed cabs. We had a great stay, with only one real problem - they put us into a room with only two single beds - we had paid and requested a King/Queen plus a single for our little girl. After 30 minutes of phone calls they put us into a suite. Apart from that, a great place in a great location, allthough it does get quiet during the evening, but the subway is across the street, and in 10 minutes you are in midtown.

Reviews.Title: “ooohhh... that plasma...”
Reviews.Author: Neilbond007
Reviews.Content: Myself and my girlfriend travelled to NY for a 4 day break (Nov 19th to 23rd). We arrived in NY fairly late on the saturday night (arrived at the hotel at around 9pm). check in was very good. asked for not too high a room as i suffer from vertigo. was offered a room on the 9th floor but braved the 17th floor! the room was pretty nice. the bed was extremely comforatble and the bathroom was a good size with a powerful shower. Plasma TV was superb! one negative was even from the 17th floor there was a lot of noise from the work going on at ground zero and some roadworks by the side of the hotel. earplugs soon sorted that out though. after we'd thrown down our bags we decided to walk and find a bar to grab a couple of beers and a snack. that was the hard part. walked to 2 TGI friday's - they were noth closed! after about 30 minutes we found an irish bar that although lacking in food, made up for it on the beer front! we ended up picking up some food from a deli and taking it back to the hotel. the next 3 days were largely spent out of the hotel. the area of the hotel is a ghost town after 8pm, but it's a short subway trip to the livelier areas. i paid about £125 a night for my room. cheap by NY standards due no doubt to the thanksgiving holidays. no business people = lower than normal prices i guess. the week prior, and after our trip the prices were around double this! £125 - superb value.... £250? i'd want somewhere closer to the action.

Reviews.Title: “Not so far out of the way.”
Reviews.Author: 1kauai
Reviews.Content: The lobby of the hotel is small and not architecturally appealing, but the lobby staff is courteouse and effective at checking guest in. We were able to check in by 11:00am and had a room on the 47th floor overlooking the WTC site and the Hudson river. The rooms are small but comfortable. I did notice that you can hear people in the halls and surrounding rooms. The 3rd floor bar is ok, but found the cocktails at the lobby bar to be served with more enthusiasm. Even though the hotel is in the finacial district downtown, you can still reach any midtown or uptown destination easily via the subways. The "E" train is just outside the door and the "2,3" a block up at Chambers street. The hotel was above average during our stay (11-18 to 11-21), however; we prefer the Ritz Carlton at Battery Park.

Reviews.Title: “Great view- pleasant stay”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for Christmas with my fiancee. The view from the 40th floor is beautiful. The bed was really comfy but for the price the room was rather small.- But you are paying for the hotel name and the plasma TV in the room.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic views - excellent service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Have never written a review like this before, but following the most excellent 3 night stay at the Millenium Hilton felt compelled to recommend it to all. Having stayed in several pricey, but generally lousy, New York hotels this place was a cut above. Comfortable, spacious rooms with amazing views and friendly and exceedingly helpful staff, in a great location.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay At The Millenium”
Reviews.Author: JBBO3314
Reviews.Content: I stayed here 2 nights with my wife and could not have had a better time we stayed on the 33rd floor. We had a view right out at ground zero which I did not see since 9-11 so it was a learning experience as far as accesing the damage. The room service was great and the mini bar is a tease but for those prices I could not touch it. So I advise anyone who stays to not look in there because it 's gonna get you. I would recommend this to all peole for all different reasons.

Reviews.Title: “Superb Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: A group of 6 of us stayed here for 3 nights and we had a fabulous time. We were on the 31st floor with rooms next to one another. We arrived at 1pm but our room wasn't ready, this wasn't a problem the hotel stored our luggage and we went out for a wander. We came across a TGI Fridays and had some nibbles and cocktails. When we returned to the hotel our rooms were ready. The rooms were perfect very clean and a great size with magnificant views of the hudson river and of course the rather humbling view of ground zero. We spent the evening in one of the rooms getting room service and drinks and just looking out the window at the awesome sight that is new york. Room service was excellant. The staff are very helpful and friendly. We found battery park was in walking distance and from here you can get tickets for the open top bus tours which can drop you at all the places you want to go. The Essex World Cafe is great for breakfast cross the road at the front of the hotel turn left along the front of the fence at ground zero. Turn right at the end of the fence and the Cafe is across the road, they do fabulous pancakes!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Hazy-Sunshine
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed for 4 nights and would definately stay there again. We had a high floor room with a view of ground zero and the hudson river. The room was of average size, clean and comfortable, the 42" TV is a good addition, although we would have liked bath robes too. The staff were both friendly and helpful and the room service was good. We have never stayed downtown before but when the subway tickets are so cheap and there are plenty of things to do and see close by, we would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Hilton - a great option”
Reviews.Author: rkachur
Reviews.Content: After struggling to find a hotel room under $250, I finally used priceline and got the Millenium Hilton for $200/night. I would definitely recommend this hotel. From what I understand the majority of the rooms have king-sized beds and views of ground zero, which also means views of the Hudson river. My husband and I didn't come here to see ground zero but rather to visit with friends but this hotel is perfectly located for those doing the touristy thing. It's close to the subway (1,9, A, C, E) and directly across the street from the PATH train. The area has everything you would need - coffee shops, shopping, etc. I expected downtown to be desolate but it isn't. The hotel is very clean and the rooms have recently been renovated. Although the rooms are probably typical NYC size (small) they are so well-designed that you hardly realize it. Our room had a plasma tv, a sleek desk with internet access, a sitting chair, a king sized bed and huge windows looking out over NY. The bathroom was huge and had big towels and crabtree & evelyn products. The only bummer was that there was not a coffee maker in our room so we had to schlep downstairs to get some. We also made the mistake of eating breakfast in the hotel restaurant one morning. Although it was good, it cost us $20/person. Pretty hefty when we could have crossed the street and gotten the same thing for half the price. Overall, I would stay here again in a heartbeat and would recommend this hotel to anyone visiting NYC.

Reviews.Title: “Oh my god! ”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My favorite Hotel in New York City - and I have stayed at quite a few. From the moment you walk thru the beautiful revolving doors - you just know. Due to a celebration - they were so kind to give us the 54th floor with a breathtaking view. I am very particular when it comes to cleaniness and the room could not have been any cleaner. We had 2 beautiful bathrooms (separate ones was great - lol) Girls, lots of room to put all our stuff! Loved the flat screen T.V. in the wall - everything was just so perfect. The only thing to watch for is ordering room service - wow it could be real expensive - but we had so much fun doing it once - it was all worthed. You will love the Millenium - it just doesn't get better than this. The most comfortable beds. Deli's all over - shopping next door - go to Little Italy! ENJOY!

Reviews.Title: “Great Choice”
Reviews.Author: Mesa-AZ
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a standard king room for 4 nights in this recently renovated hotel. This hotel exceeded our expectations. We found a good rate on the Hilton website and prepaid, and there were no "extra charge" surprises on the bill at checkout. They placed us on the 12th floor. The room was extremely clean and comfortable. The bath was excellent. We enjoyed a wide view of the Hudson River. This hotel is in a perfect location for exploring the south end of Manhattan - look up the free shuttle buses operated by the Downtown Alliance to get around the south end. There are scads of places nearby to grab a reasonable breakfast sandwich or deli lunch. In July they did not have coffee pots in the room. Hotel was well-staffed and any help we needed was provided promptly and courteously. We prearranged our transportation to & from the airport with Carmel Limo service (full-size sedan) and will use them again.

Reviews.Title: “A Really Nice Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: SueFee
Reviews.Content: In our previous visits to New York City, we've always stayed in midtown Manhattan. However, when our usual hotel was booked solid, we decided to give the Millenium Hilton a try---and we were glad we did! We paid about $30/night extra for a room on the 31st-55th floor and got one on the 35th floor. The view is bittersweet---great city and Jersey views but sad at the same time since you are reminded of what used to be across the street. The hotel is very clean and housekeeping is excellent--very consistent. Every night we were there, they had turn-down service. Not only did they turn down the bedcovers but they filled the ice bucket and left two bottles of water and two pieces of chocolate. As others pointed out, the toiletries are nice---Crabtree and Evelyn. The flat-screen plasma TV is nice, too. The only problem with that is the way it's positioned, you need to sit on the bed to see it or position the desk chair so that it faces the TV. We found the bed to be very comfortable and even though we were near the elevator and ice machine, we never had a problem with noise. The closet is small but it met our needs just fine. Elevator service is great--prompt and fast--we never had a problem with that. At this hotel, you are very close to several subway lines so getting around the city is quite easy. We didn't eat at the hotel restaurant since there are so many other options available in NYC. Plus, you can get a much cheaper breakfast elsewhere. In short, we would gladly stay here again! While we would have preferred a room on the other side of the hotel, we discovered that only the suites and junior suites face in the other direction---so it would have been more expensive.

Reviews.Title: “A+ Hotel, A+ Location, A+ View, A+ Value”
Reviews.Author: seamus266
Reviews.Content: Arrived via Amtrak from Phiadelphia at 1PM Sept. 9 for a 3 night stay. Despite being early check-in, they had a room on the 45th floor ready and awaiting my arrival. First, realize this hotel is downtown, near Wall St. and immediately across the street from Ground Zero. Built in the early 1990's, the hotel was damaged by the scumbags, closed for nearly 2 years, and completely re-vamped. I stayed in the regular 1King bed room. This is the most basic room at the hotel. For more $ you can get a junior suite, which offers some more room, and a view that looks more uptown rather than downtown. Some consider this a plus. For me, ground zero, the buildings around ground zero, the Hudson River with its traffic, and NJ and the sunsets made my view the best in the hotel. All rooms offer the large plasma TV, nice work table with convenient internet and electrical plugs, floor to ceiling windows and in-room safe. No in-room wireless internet (wireless in lobby/lounge/restaurant only). They charge $5.95 per 24 hours, or $9.95 if you must log on to your own internet provider. They will give you the T1 cord for a $10 deposit. Rooms very comfortable. Bed nice and well appointed with sheets and comforter. Closet small-enough room for 1 person but would be stretching it for 2 people. The dresser is dominated by mini-bar, mini-refer which doesn't leave a lot of drawer space. Bathrooms very nice w/marble and a good shower up high so someone 6'2" or so doesn't have to bend over to wash hair. Towels and bathroom amenities servicable. Note only one sink-may be 2 in the junior suite - if that's an issue, check. Not only is the room comfortable and new, the view is stunning. I was there for the 911 aniversary/memorial. To look out and see the crowds and the firetrucks and police cars and mourners and everyone else paying their respects was staggering. To be able to walk out the door and across the street and be Right There was amazing. A lot of people suggest staying up towards ( or in) Times Square so you can really be a part of the party. I disagree and am more than happy I stayed at the M. Hilton. 15 minute walk to L.Italy/Chinatown. 15 to Wall St. 15 to ferry boats to NJ. Anything further, there is a subway stop a block away, or just catch a cab. It is quieter and less congested down here than up at Times Sq. It is convenient to go up in the evening, see Times, see the lights and masses of people and hawkers, and for me; cool to leave it behind and come back to the hotel. Also, restaurant and room service both very good - if you do get room service, realize you are paying $4 plus 15% on top of the price of food. This is the tip. Don't leave more money after you are already forced to tip (unless you are just really generous - if so, give me a call). I had no time for pool and no need for work-out after all the hiking I did each day, so I can not comment on either of those facilities. My minor complaint: while room was clean, there were a couple strands of hair in tub. I seem to see this almost everywhere I stay, yet I don't like it and find it disquieting - once I see that I question the cleanliness of the rest of the room and am on the lookout for something else to complain about. Other very minor incident - on 9/11 I removed DND sign from door and went to GZ. Returned 2 hrs. later and room not yet cleaned. Called housekeeping then took computer down to lounge, had a drink, sent a couple emails, returned 50 minutes later, and room was completed. No big deal. I will certainly stay at the Millenium Hilton again. In fact, I am already planning my next trip in 2006 to NYC, and have no cause to stay anywhere else. Last advice, if you do stay at a Hilton property, become a member of their frequent guest club. 500 miles per stay or a couple other options. If you like to fly first class you can't beat incentive bonuses.

Reviews.Title: “Clean, comfortable, and Great staff”
Reviews.Author: PT1976
Reviews.Content: Booked a room on hotwire for $202 (174 + tax) a few days before our Friday night visit. We called a day earlier to ask if we could check in at noon and receptionist was frosty, said she couldn't guarantee anything. Arrival was easy; there's an ACE and 123 stop (Chambers St) just steps from the hotel. We arrived at noon and the front desk clerk was gracious and accomodating and found us a room on the 41st floor facing the world trade center site and the river. Great views. Decor was generic but the bed was comfortable and linens pristine. Bathroom was decently sized, had a nice tub, Crabtree and Evelyn toiletries, and a shaving mirror. This was definitely a nice business-type hotel. Location was perfect for us because we prefer downtown and it was nice to be close to Brooklyn where our friends live. Cons included lack of decent food (except a deli) around the corner. Plus, this part of the city is quieter and you can get anywhere in minutes using the subway. Front desk was exceptionally friendly and helpful - they are what makes this place stand out.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Hilton - You Can't Go Wrong Here !!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I read all the reviews with skepticism. I've been disappointed before with New York hotels. This time, however, I was not. From the moment you walk off the sidewalk, you realize this hotel is upscale. The location is incredible: right across the street from the World Trade Center plaza and in walking distance to many attractions. There are also several wonderful restaurants within a few blocks. Be sure to check out St. Paul's Chapel right next door. It was built in 1766 and has a cemetary on the grounds with stones dating back to the 1700's. George Washington has a special pew in the church. This was a resting spot for the volunteers in the 9/11 tragedy and there is a lot of memorabilia and photos on display. A must-see. But get there early - as I recall visiting hours end around 3 p.m. As for the hotel, the rooms are not large, but they are very comfortable and extremely clean. The beds are superb with down comforters, and each room has a large flat panel television. The hotel is well constructed and the rooms are quiet. The only noise you will hear is the plumbing, but I doubt there is anything that could be done about that. As you might expect, the food here is expensive. I only had the breakfast buffet (once), but it set me back around $20. Pricey by anyone's standards. The views are incredible. I stayed on the 23rd floor and had a perfect view straight down into "ground zero". It really made me reflect on the heroism shown and the lives lost in that tragedy. The service at this hotel is also superb. I felt like the staff went out of their way to make sure everything was perfect. From the front desk to the bellmen, they were all just top-notch. I paid $389 per night, which would be exorbitant in any other city in the country, but I felt like I got my money's worth here. I stayed here three nights in late August, and I'll not hesitate to stay here again when I return to New York.

Reviews.Title: “Great...for the price!”
Reviews.Author: montrealitgirl
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here after having camped in the Adirondaks for a few days. This was to be the "pampering" part of our vacation...2 nights in New York! I got our room on priceline for 150! I was willing to pay more for a 4 star or 5 star hotel....but that's what i got. I was a little dissapointed when i found out where it was located... across from ground zero! could i handle the emotional impact of being in that location? upon arrival, we requested a " high floor" and king... got both! we were on the 29th floor in a "delux king" VERY big for New York! and yes, the plasma T.V. is huge... but better yet, the bathroom is quite large...with marble and nice Crabtree and Evelyne ammenities. The bed was extremely comfy....and the view was spectacular....we were over-looking ground zero...which was disturbing and sad at first... but it is moving to see that life goes on...we had a beautifull view of the Hudson as well. The decor is a little drab for my taste ..tres modern, but clean and crisp looking. now, for the bad....well, it just feels like a hotel that is pretending to be a 4 star hotel...kinda quickly put together. The lobby for example is small and lacks personality...as does the bar. the staff is courteous enough, but you don't feel special arriving here...i don't know, just lacks a certain je ne sais quoi! BUT the location close to subways, the size of the rooms, and the sleek newness of it all makes it worth it...especially for 150/night! TIPS: century 21 is amazing for deals...got a Marc Jacobs bag for 100...which is 300 reg! also, went to a fabulous restaurant called Kittichai in Soho! to die for... try the chocolat ribs as an appetizer. also, the stage door deli for breaky is the way to go....oh, and you gotta go to Carmines'for some HUGE portions ( i am not kidding do NOT order more than one plate for 2-3 people! i love New York!

Reviews.Title: “Superb 10 out 10”
Reviews.Author: bugspins
Reviews.Content: Stay at the Millenium the last weekend of July 2005. This hotel and staff are simply fantastic. Arrived in New York for a 3 day visit before heading to Orlando. Arrived at hotel around 1pm and went straight to our room. kids loved the large Plasma screen TV. All the staff were really friendly. Try the back stage deli around the corner for a great breakfast or lunch. Metro is only 1min walk away so easy to get around. Several good restaurants near by to. Will definately go back again and again. 10 out 10.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel - staff keep to themselves”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Very happy with the Hilton. Across the street from subway so you can get anywhere pretty quickly. The staff were good but really kept to themselves, which i like. Not very central but easy to get to on the subway. Cool TV's in the rooms!

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Iffy Location”
Reviews.Author: enofile1
Reviews.Content: The Millenium Hotel is everything you would want in a large urbane hotel. The rooms are quite large for NYC and have great views. The service is warm and accommodating, and the prices are excellent. So what seems to be the issue? The location is directly next to Ground Zero and although I applaud the hotel for opening up again shortly after 9/11, the area is very eerie, especially at night. There simply is not much to do at this downtown location except shop at Century 21 across the street. If you do not mind the subway or taking cabs, it might work for you. As for me, I rather be in the heart of one of New York's more vibrant neighborhoods.

Reviews.Title: “Sleek, stylish, great subway location”
Reviews.Author: foursquarebar
Reviews.Content: Got a corner king city-view room for just under $300 a night, after taxes, which was not too bad considering the good location, convenience, and *amazing* city view from the room. We usually stay in Midtown and enjoyed being away from the congestion of that area. The sleek black tower was easy to find and next to the WTC site. St. Paul's Church right beside the hotel has some compelling exhibits and stories about 9/11 inside and a very old graveyard that is beautiful and parklike. Good shopping is close by too. My spouse was duly impressed for his 40th birthday. Furnishings are modern, and wow did he love the flat screen tv on the wall. Nice beds too. (I continue to *hate* the fridge with the hugely marked-up items and no room for your own soda or water.) In NYC, you don't spend too much time in the room, but we had a chance to enjoy a bottle of wine while gazing out over Manhattan at night, lovely! We appreciated the wine glasses and corkscrew in the room, and I liked the Crabtree & Evelyn toiletries. We did not take advantage of the pool, the lobby bar, or the Church & Dey restaurant, too many other things to do. We did notice that there was wireless in the bar and restaurant, and the lobby bar always seemed busy. My husband is a huge subway fan and loved our central location for getting just about any train we needed, from Midtown to Coney Island. The location is extremely convenient. I'd stay here again in a regular room if I could get some of the under-$200 prices that others seem to be snagging. Normally, I go budget, but this place came through for me when I needed a special occasion room without seeing it first. I will continue to wonder why this hotel spells its own name wrong. Don't let that steer you away. :-)

Reviews.Title: “Anniversary Getaway”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Millenium Hilton is a find in lower Manhattan. For the price (we got a $177.00 per night deal) it was a real charm. This hotel has been nicely renovated to a more edgy funky look but not over the top like some NY hotels. Clean too. Our room was on the 53rd floor, corner overlooking Brooklyn to the East and ground zero to the southwest. Nice and quiet and cosy too. Very romantic overall. Big bathroom and spacious by NYC standards. Located on several subway lines so a quick ride to Midtown and Penn Station. Also located by Century 21 and SYMS for discount shopping. Starbucks is located around the corner for breakfast. Helpful desk staff and concierge. Much better service than in some of the smaller, boutique hotels located in Midtown.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay---though out of the way for tourists”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent six nights at the Millenium Hilton during our first ever stay in New York City. We were on an award stay from Hilton, and they put us in a very nice 25th floor two-room suite over looking Ground Zero---which can only be described as a sobering view. Because of our frequent travel status, we did receive free breakfast coupons, which were great because the breakfast buffet (while very good) costs roughly $25 a head. There are a bunch of places within walking distance for breakfast and lunch, though you will find your dinner options a little limited. The room was very clean and upscale. The beds were quite comfortable, and the sitting room had a fridge, work area, and separate sitting area. The bathroom had a great shower, and the bedroom had a very large flat screen television. If anyone in your crowd likes to shop, the hotel is located right next door to Century 21---which for those of you from the south, is a little like a Steinmart or TJ Maxx on steriods. The only downside, at least for those of us in the tourist crowd, is the location of the hotel compared to midtown attractions. You are a $12-15 cab ride, or a pretty lengthy subway ride to midtown---even more if you are going to the museums on either the upper east or upper west side. Many could see this as a positive, since this hotel is in a very quiet part of town. On the upside, however, you are within a block of two very large subway stations, from which you can catch nearly any of the major lines. The subway is very easy to use, though if you catch a local train, it is probably a 15-25 minute ride into midtown---and you will want to cab it back to this hotel if you come back late at night. Finally, leaving the hotel is quite easy. The bell station arranged all of our travel back to the airport, and actually found us a town car that cost us less than our cab ride in to town.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Hotel”
Reviews.Author: PattiJ
Reviews.Content: We had a suite on the 52nd floor overlooking Ground Zero. For me, this was very emotional and unnerving. However, when I thought about the fact that all of these people working here have to deal with this, and may have actually gone through 9/11 across the street, I realized that we all have to do what we have to do and move on. Back to the hotel: I got an exc. deal: $300/nite for a suite (king bed & sleeper sofa). The staff was wonderful and the hotel was convenient to many attractions. My kids loved the pool and I loved the turndown service. I'd stay here again in a heartbeat!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Views, Wonderful NYC Retreat!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We traveled by train from Washington DC to New York on the weekend of July 28th. We had requested an early check-in but when we arrived at the hotel at 8:00 a.m. we did not really expect that our room would be ready at that early hour. We were wrong! Not only was the room ready, but our corner-view room on the 48th floor had as spectacular a view as one could imagine. One wall of windows framed a breathtaking view of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Manhattan Bridge, and the East River. The other windows looked out toward the Statue of Liberty, and of course, over the site of the World Trade Center. The view of the WTC site was sobering but we were also struck by how resilient the city remains, not only by the expansive view, but by the overall vibrancy of the city. The hotel was very impressive, attractive, well-staffed and extremely well-priced by NYC standards. The room, with it's contemporary furnishings, comfortable size, nice plasma television, was a relaxing retreat after our days and evenings out on the town. The only drawback, and it was a minor one, was that the financial district is not well-stocked with good restaurants. However, Tribeca/Soho and the city beyond are only a short walk away, and buses/subways/cabs are at the hotel's doorstep.

Reviews.Title: “Very good hotel”
Reviews.Author: sfrick
Reviews.Content: Our daughter and her husband were living in Brooklyn (DUMBO) which has almost no hotels. The Millenium's location was perfect as we could walk across the bridge or take 3 different subway lines to within a 10 minute walk of their apartment. Also, all the Manhattan lines converge near the hotel so getting uptown was also very easy. The rooms were spacious with incredible views and the staff was very helpful. The only problems had to do with arrival/departure as it can get very congested in front of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “A top hotel”
Reviews.Author: RedSpyder
Reviews.Content: Excellent rooms and service and a great location. Good value for Manhattan. No problems whatsoever.

Reviews.Title: “Great VIEW, Great Room, Great Staff, GREAT PRICE”
Reviews.Author: nolatravel
Reviews.Content: Stayed with my girlfriend in this hotel from a Friday to Sunday - checked in from another hotel at 9am with no problem even though check in time was 3pm - requested a "high floor" on reservation and got it (53/55) the view was incredible. Everything about the hotel seemed clean and new (I gather it was renovated post 9/11) – operable slit window was great as the weather was nice and cool - large plasma tv a plus, but went largely unwatched as there is so much to do outside. The bellman were nice and helpful, they kept our baggage for us when we checked out as we took a late flight from JFK - The A train / Air Train to JFK worked fine for me but I would allow 3 hours prior to departure to be on the safe side. The view, especially the sunset was amazing – things to do nearby include Battery Park City, The Federal Reserve of New York, New York Stock Exchange (from the outside-no tours) A jogging / bike path (Westside Greenway) running from Battery Park City past the World Financial Center up the Cloisters Museum (past GW bridge). Friday Sunset. Sunday Brunch sails on SV Ventura from North Cove Harbor (WFC) - Walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. J&R Music world for electronics of all types. A Starbucks on every block. Watched the beginnings of this hotel being constructed in 1989 while working in NYC and always wanted to stay there based strictly on it's exterior appearance and glad I did - (a tall slender building of 55 floors with a 12:1 ratio of height to width). I would highly recommend the views, room quality, and service - PLUS - it happens to be the cheapest hotel in Manhattan. Overlooks the former, now empty (except for a path station) WTC site – if this bothers you, you would not want to stay here, though there are some rooms with East River views, and views further downtown to the south and midtown to the north.

Reviews.Title: “July 4th Holiday at the Millenium Hilton”
Reviews.Author: drgnfly30
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millenium Hilton from July 3-6th.... Paid $229 with 2 free breakfast buffett coupons per day as a part of their BounceBack deal that I booked directly from their website. We took the path over from NJ to save on the $45 per night parking fee. The hotel couldn't have been more convenient to the Path station. We had a double room for me, husband & sons 15 & 10... , we were in room 2001 on the 20th floor facing Century 21 & the WTC site, it was apparently one of the larger standard rooms.. WOW if these rooms are big for NYC I'd hate to see an average room! The 2 double beds appeared to be smaller than doubles I've slept on in the past..(we joked it's not a California King but a Manhattan Double!) Because they were so small we called for a roll away for DS10 - it was $25 for the entire stay. The TV was cool. The shower heads were small & I would have expected something a bit more posh for the hotel. No turn down service however the first night there were some chocolates sitting on the mini bar but nothing after that.The Stage Deli that was mentioned in other reviews was great! We ate their twice... if you want delivery late at night we found the only thing was Charleys - their Pizza was WAY too greasy. The breakfast buffett was perfect... since it was free as a part of our BounceBack rate... I'd never pay $18.95 Plus Tax for it!! The pool was nice, especially for the kids. While we weren't in the thick of NY, we appreciated the 'down' time & the subways were easily navigated with a small subway map we got from the NYC tourism site. We took a taxi back from the Circle Line (pier 83 or so?) for about $15. I'd definately consider staying here again for the right price...

Reviews.Title: “Great deal and good service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed here in May with 4 of my girlfriends in a suite. There was a king size bed and separate living room with a sleep sofa. We got the suited for $299/night. Compared to some of the hotels in New York the space was right on time. The rooms were very clean but beware of the mini-bar. If you touch or remove anything it will be reflected on the bill. My girlfriend moved a beer to place a beverage in the refrigerator and promptly informed the front desk of the situation. An inventory of the items will be taken when you leave and any issues can be settled then. Did I mention the plasma TV to watch by the bed and the 32 in. in the separate living room area. The hotel is DIRECTLY across from Ground Zero/Subway and view was spectacular. Hard to imagine the chaos and horror of 9-11.
